/C15 A new /uniFB02 uorescent chemosensor comprised of Q[8] and acridine has been designed for the recognition of amino acids.

/C15 A /uniFB02 uorescence method for the detection of /uniFB01 ve amino acids using a single system has been developed.

Amino acids are of huge biological signi /uniFB01 cance, and are not only constituents of peptides, proteins, and alike but also play pivotal roles in the transport of materials and in biosynthesis [1,2]. Arginine (Arg) for example plays a central physiological role in a variety of transformations including cell division, gene regulation, healing of wounds and the release of hormones [3 e 5]. Moreover, Arg is used to treat diseases resulting from endocrine and high ammonia reactions [6,7]. Similarly, histidine (His) is critical for many enzymatic processes [8], whilst it has been reported that decreases in His levels are observed in patients suffering from lung cancer [9 e 13]. In the case of lysine, it is linked to the Krebs-Henseleit cycle and to polyamine synthesis [14,15], whilst high levels of lysine in the plasma and urine are indicators of congenital metabolic disorders, for example cystinuria or hyperlysinemia [16,17]. The amino acid phenylalanine (Phe) is extensively employed both in the food and pharmaceutical industries. Examples of the use of Phe include as an intermediate in the production of anti-cancer drugs, as a nutritional additive, and as an additive in food and drink [18]. Finally, from a biological perspective, tryptophan (Trp) plays an important role in human metabolism [19] and is associated with the likes of diabetes and nerve disorders [20]. The selective recognition of amino acids is thus highly desirable for a variety of medicinal reasons (see Scheme 1).

Wenote that a range of traditional detection methods for amino acids have previously been developed, including high-performance liquid chromatography, ion-exchange chromatography as well as gas chromatography [21 e 23]. However, such detection methods suffer from a number of de /uniFB01 ciencies, namely that they are somewhat complicated, not cheap, can be awkward to use, exhibit poor selectivity, lack precision and sensitivity, and also suffer from a lack of reproducibility [24]. This has led to recent increased interest in the potential of host-guest chemistry, and a boost to progress in the area of molecular recognition [25 e 27]. This increased interest in aqueous host-guest chemistry has led to the availability of analyte responsive host-dye systems based on macrocycles or so-called host-dye /uniFB02 uorescence indicator displacement (FID) systems. Such FID systems are now attracting the interest of researchers as agreeable alternatives to the more traditional chemosensors [28,29].

Cucurbit [ n ]urils (Q [ n ]s), a family of synthetic macrocycles, are capable of binding amines over a wide af /uniFB01 nity range (10 3 to 10 12 M 1 ) in aqueous solution, and for this reason have attracted /C0 interest for both molecular recognition and in molecular devices [30 e 39]. Over the past 10 years or so, Q[ n ]s and derivatives thereof have been shown to interact with a number of speci /uniFB01 c amino acids, peptides, and proteins [40 e 48]. However, given that amino acids have in common the same types of functional groups, namely carboxylic/CO2H and amino/NH2 groups, the manufacture of sensors capable of detecting speci /uniFB01 c amino acids with both signi /uniFB01 cant sensitivity and selectivity remains a key target. Reports on the use of cucurbit [ n ]uril-based host-dye /uniFB02 uorescence indicator displacement systems for amino acid detection remain scant. In 2011, Quintana reported an electrochemical sensor which employed the host-guest interactions of Q[8], and was applied to the determination of tryptophan in ' real ' samples displaying reasonable accuracy and precision [49]. In 2017, our group reported two /uniFB02 uorescent probes based on two alkyl-substituted cucurbit [6]urils and a cationic vinylpyridine containing dye. These probes were capable of recognizing lysine and methionine versus a number of other a -amino acids in aqueous solution [50]. More recently, Yang et al. synthesized an ambient temperature phosphorescent (RTP) cyclodextrin-Q [6]-co-wheeled [4]rotaxane, and utilized it for the highly speci /uniFB01 c sensing of Trp. It was noted that the strong green emission associated with the RTP was quenched in the presence of Trp, whereas when other physiologically relevant amino acids were added, no such quenching was evident [51].

Herein, a cucurbit [ n ]uril-based host-dye /uniFB02 uorescence indicator has been assembled from Q[8] and acridine hydrochloride (AC). The interaction between Q[8] and AC was studied by a number of spectroscopic methods including /uniFB02 uorescence, UV e vis and 1 HNMR spectroscopy. From the data accumulated, a 1:2 host-guest inclusion complex was identi /uniFB01 ed. Interestingly, free AC is known to be strongly /uniFB02 uorescent, however the /uniFB02 uorescence was quenched for this Q[8]-AC inclusion complex. To this Q[8]-AC system, 20 natural amino acids were added; phenylalanine (Phe) and tryptophan (Trp) both resulted in a signi /uniFB01 cant ampli /uniFB01 cation of the green /uniFB02 uorescence intensity of the inclusion complex, while basic amino acids exhibited blue /uniFB02 uorescence. These results demonstrated the ability to detect /uniFB01 ve amino acids in a single system using a /uniFB02 uorescence method.

2.2. The response of the Q[8]-AC inclusion complex to different Lamino acids

In order to detect amino acids by /uniFB02 uorescence, a non/uniFB02 uorescent host-guest system was designed, thereby allowing for the facile ' turn-on ' /uniFB02 uorescence sensing of amino acids. As mentioned above, this new host-guest Q[8]-AC inclusion complex is non/uniFB02 uorescent and exhibits good solubility in water. In order to discover whether the Q[8]-AC inclusion complex prepared herein could be employed to identify natural amino acids, a number of /uniFB02 uorescence experiments were conducted using each of the natural amino acids.
In addition, we obtained single crystals of AC 2@Q[8]. Since the solubility of Q[8] in neutral aqueous solutions is poor, the crystallization of Q[8]-AC was performed in an aqueous solution of HCl (6.0 M) via the introduction of [CdCl4] 2-. In order to more fully understand the mechanism of recognition of the Q[8]-AC complex towards amino acids, 1 HNMRspectroscopy was employed using the L -Phe or L -Trp and Q[8]-AC systems in D2O solution (pD ¼ 4). As shown in Fig. 8, when L -Phe was added to the Q[8]-AC solution, the aromatic protons (H1, H2, and H3) and the methylene proton (H4) underwent a clear up /uniFB01 eld shift, while proton H5 exhibited a down /uniFB01 eld shift, which indicated that the aryl ring and methylene of the L -Phe can be found encapsulated within the cavity of the Q[8]. The remaining part of L -Phe is out of the Q[8] portal, the result being an inclusion complex between Q[8] and L -Phe. Then, upon adding L -Phe to the Q[8]-AC inclusion complex in D2O, all the proton resonances for the guest AC associated with the Q[8]-AC inclusion complex appeared to shift down /uniFB01 eld (Ha ¼ 0.23; Hb ¼ 0.21; Hc ¼ 0.19; Hd ¼ 0.21; He ¼ 0.09 ppm) (Fig. 8), which suggested that these protons were gradually exiting from the Q[8] cavity. Concomitantly, the protons (H1, H2, H3, and H4) of L -Phe shifted to lower /uniFB01 eld compared to L -Phe in the inclusion complex. These observations demonstrated that the L -Phe molecule was capable of replacing the included AC molecule in the Q[8] cavity. Based on these observations, a possible interaction model between L -Phe and Q[8]-AC is shown in Fig. 8 (insert). For comparison, upon addition of D -Phe to the Q[8]-AC inclusion complex in D2O, the same phenomenon was observed (Fig. S21).

In summary, a new ' on-off-on ' /uniFB02 uorescent chemosensor based on cucuribit [8]uril (Q[8]) and acridine hydrochloride (AC) has been successfully constructed and utilized for the recognition of different amino acids. In aqueous solution, AC was encapsulated within the Q [8] cavity to form a 1:2 host-guest inclusion complex, which was veri /uniFB01 ed in the solid-state by a single-crystal X-ray structural determination. Free AC is known to be strongly /uniFB02 uorescent, however this strong /uniFB02 uorescence was extinguished in the Q[]-AC inclusion complex. This non/uniFB02 uorescent Q[8]-AC complex served as a /uniFB02 uorescence ' off-on ' probe capable of recognizing L -Phe or L -Trp, owing to the competitive interaction between L -Phe or L-Trp; the included AC molecule is replaced by the L -Phe or L -Trp molecule in the Q[8] cavity. This /uniFB02 uorescent chemosensor also possessed pHresponsiveness, where the addition of basic L-amino acids (L-Arg, L-His or L-Lys) caused blue shift /uniFB02 uorescence changes for the Q[8]AC complex. This work led to a /uniFB02 uorescence method for the detection of /uniFB01 ve amino acids in a single system. The method presented in this investigation represents a promising potential practical application for the detection of amino acids.
